title: هَمْزَة الْوَصْل وَالْقَطْع
description: Learn the rules for همزة الوصل (connecting hamza) vs همزة القطع (cutting hamza) - when each is used, how they are written, and their pronunciation rules.

notes.title: What is همزة الوصل?
content: هَمْزَة الْوَصْل (connecting hamza) is a hamza that is pronounced at the beginning of speech but dropped when preceded by another word. It is written as bare alif (ا) without the hamza sign (ء).

It is called 'وَصْل' (connection) because when connected to a preceding word, it drops and allows smooth connection. For example: 'اِقْرَأْ' alone starts with hamza, but in 'وَاقْرَأْ', the hamza is not pronounced.
keyPoints: هَمْزَة الْوَصْل = drops when connected to preceding word
Written as ا without ء sign
Pronounced only at beginning of speech

notes.title: What is همزة القطع?
content: هَمْزَة الْقَطْع (cutting/disjunctive hamza) is a hamza that is always pronounced, whether at the beginning of speech or in the middle of a sentence. It is written with the hamza sign (أ or إ).
It is called 'قَطْع' (cutting) because it 'cuts' or interrupts the flow - it must always be pronounced. This is the 'true' hamza that represents an actual consonant sound.
keyPoints: Written with أ (with fatha/damma) or إ (with kasra)
Represents the actual glottal stop consonant

notes.title: Where همزة الوصل Occurs
content: هَمْزَة الْوَصْل occurs in specific places: 1) The definite article ال, 2) The imperative of three-letter verbs (اِفْعَلْ), 3) The past, imperative, and masdar of Forms VII-X (اِنْفَعَلَ، اِفْتَعَلَ، etc.), 4) Ten specific nouns: اِسْم، اِبْن، اِبْنَة، اِثْنَان، اِثْنَتَان، اِمْرُؤ، اِمْرَأَة، اِسْت، أَيْمُن، أَيْم.
The vowel of hamzat al-wasl depends on the third letter of the verb: if the third letter has damma, the hamza takes damma (اُكْتُبْ); otherwise it takes kasra (اِقْرَأْ).

notes.title: Where همزة القطع Occurs
content: هَمْزَة الْقَطْع is the default - it occurs everywhere except the specific places where hamzat al-wasl is used. Key locations include: 1) All nouns except the ten listed for wasl, 2) All particles (إِلَى، أَنَّ، إِنَّ، أَوْ، etc.), 3) Past tense of Forms I-IV (أَكَلَ، أَخْرَجَ), 4) Imperative of Form IV (أَخْرِجْ).
The past and imperative of Form IV have hamzat al-qat' because Form IV's distinguishing feature is the added أ at the beginning: فَعَلَ → أَفْعَلَ.
keyPoints: Default: assume قَطْع unless specific وَصْل case

notes.title: Practical Rules and Common Mistakes
content: To test whether a hamza is وَصْل or قَطْع, add وَ or فَ before the word: if the hamza is still pronounced, it's قَطْع (وَأَكَلَ); if it drops, it's وَصْل (وَاقْرَأْ).
Common mistakes include writing اسم with hamza (wrong: أَسْم) or writing إنتصر instead of اِنْتَصَر. Remember: Form VII-X always have hamzat al-wasl in the past tense.
keyPoints: Test: add وَ - if hamza pronounced = قَطْع, if dropped = وَصْل
اِسْم not أَسْم (one of the ten nouns)
أَنْتَ، أَنَا، أَخٌ، أُمٌّ = قَطْع (pronouns and most nouns)

examples.english: in the name of Allah (اسم = wasl)
the best of names (أسماء plural = qat')

exercises.answer: connective hamza (drops when preceded by another word)
